title: Justice Mark Dreyfus and the Isaacs by-election
text:
Speaking of parliamentary passengers, speculation is now positively feverish that Labor’s shadow attorney-general Mark Dreyfus will announce his departure from federal parliament within weeks, causing a by-election in his Melbourne seat of Isaacs.

Though Victoria’s Court of Appeal president Chris Maxwell won’t reach his mandatory retirement age of 70 until January 2023, he’s said to be ready for early retirement. Dreyfus recently met Premier Dan Andrews, presumably to discuss the role – certainly not to talk level crossings in Edithvale, given the local member actually lives in Malvern.

Such an appointment would undermine the judiciary’s independence and damage the court, but wouldn’t its loss be our gain?! As a young QC in 2005, Dreyfus sought the same gig but was overlooked for Maxwell by Steve Bracks’ attorney-general Rob Hulls. That left the pompous, unexceptional silk to pursue jurisprudential glory via Canberra, deposing sitting MP Ann Corcoran in 2007 before spending an entire seven months in 2013 as the nation’s first law officer. He now serves on the opposition’s House tactics team as its unwitting devil’s advocate.

Before Bill Shorten’s shock defeat at May’s federal poll, Dreyfus was set to return as Commonwealth attorney-general, then join the High Court on the occasion of a vacancy (likely the retirement of Justice Geoffrey Nettle in December 2020), despite his ceaseless bellyaching about the Administrative Appeals Tribunal being “full of Liberal mates” and his unironic pledge to “restore a transparent merits-based policy to judicial appointments”. Dreyfus’ pungent ambition is only casually tethered to his sufferability; indeed, the two may be inversely proportionate.

Dreyfus also threatened to resign in 2016 if Kimberley Kitching was selected to fill Stephen Conroy’s vacancy in the Senate. She was, but cruelly, he didn’t.

Dreyfus wants the ALP’s unsuccessful Higgins candidate (and another barrister) Fiona McLeod to replace him in Isaacs, presumably so its parliamentary representative can continue admiring it from afar. Suffice it to say the Right will have something to say about that.

With a 6.4 per cent margin, and a profile too suburban for the Greens, the by-election promises to be uneventful, even though the government will control its timing.
description: The shadow attorney-general is set to quit parliament to lead Victoria's Court of Appeal.
